title: 114_s2932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Patient Access to Emergency Medications Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the importance of using controlled substances by emergency medical services agencies to provide timely care in the field for critical injuries and illnesses. The provision of time-sensitive and mobile medical care to individuals with critical injuries and illnesses in the field is crucial. There have been few investigations by the Drug Enforcement Administration related to diversion in emergency medical services. Regulatory oversight to prevent diversion is essential in all healthcare settings. Regulatory oversight is crucial to prevent diversion in all healthcare settings, including emergency medical services. Oversight should be tailored to unique care delivery models and promote uniformity in rules and enforcement to establish clear guidelines within emergency medical services. Establish clear guidelines for various types of emergency medical services agencies, including governmental, nongovernmental, private, and volunteer agencies. SEC. 312 of the Controlled Substances Act adds guidelines for emergency medical services agencies. The Controlled Substances Act defines emergency medical services as medical response provided outside of a facility, and emergency medical services agencies as organizations that provide such services by ground, air, or other means. The term 'emergency medical services practitioner' refers to a licensed health care provider credentialed by a medical director to deliver emergency medical services. The term 'medical director' refers to a physician providing oversight for an emergency medical services agency, including supervision of medical operations and prescribing medical criteria for administering controlled substances. The term 'verbal order' refers to a verbal prescription for administering a controlled substance in emergency medical services, while 'online medical direction' involves verbal instructions from a physician to guide patient care. The term 'registrant emergency medical services agency' refers to an agency or hospital registered under its own license to provide patient care and treatment. The Attorney General can register emergency medical services agencies to allow practitioners to dispense controlled substances to users in need of emergency medical services. The Attorney General requires a single registration per State for emergency medical services agencies, tailoring guidance to recognize existing medical care delivery and oversight. The Attorney General mandates that emergency medical services agencies in each state have medical directors for oversight of care delivery models. The agency must have at least one licensed physician serving as a medical director for oversight of emergency medical services. The medical director's responsibilities may vary based on state regulations. The medical director, appointed by the state or delegated authority, is responsible for decisions on patient transportation, approving medical protocols, and overseeing patient care by EMS practitioners. The emergency medical services agency oversees patient evaluation, treatment, interventions, online medical direction, drug formularies, medication dispensing, administering controlled substances, and medical education/training programs. The emergency medical services agency oversees medical education/training programs and quality improvement. Controlled substances in schedule II-V may be administered by EMS practitioners. Emergency medical services practitioners of a registrant agency can provide emergency medical services under standing orders or online medical direction from medical directors or licensed physicians. Emergency medical services practitioners can request verbal orders from the medical director in specific patient cases under agency policy. The medical director provides verbal orders to emergency medical services practitioners in specific patient cases to ensure proper care and treatment. Impermissible limitations on allowable orders are not allowed. The medical director can provide verbal orders to emergency medical services practitioners for patient care without being present or providing a prescription. Documentation requirements apply. Emergency medical services agencies must keep standing orders on file and make them available to the Attorney General upon request. They must also have a policy for documenting verbal orders received from online medical direction and the administration of controlled substances in patient care charts. Verbal order received from online medical direction for controlled substance administration must be documented in patient care chart and available to the Attorney General upon request. The registrant emergency medical services agency can receive controlled substances at designated locations. The registrant emergency medical services agency can receive controlled substances at designated locations and move them between agency locations without being considered a distributor under the Act. The emergency medical services agency can store controlled substances at designated locations and move them between agency locations without being classified as a distributor under the Act. This section does not affect requirements under titles XVIII or XIX of the Social Security Act. The section clarifies that it does not change requirements under titles XVIII or XIX of the Social Security Act and does not limit the Attorney General's authority to enforce diversion of controlled substances.
